awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Building a Culture of Active Learning through Course-Based Communities of Transformation
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to improve undergraduate STEM teaching for more than 20,000 students and help develop models that can improve learning in programs across the country. The primary goal of the project is to develop and support a university culture that values the incorporation of active learning practices in undergraduate STEM courses and programs. Teams of faculty, graduate students, and undergraduate students will be brought together to form course-based communities of transformation that will support these changes. Over the course of the project, communities will be created in four STEM departments that teach thousands of students in targeted gateway courses in Mathematics, Physics, Biology, and Computer Science. These multi-generational communities will receive training on active learning techniques. Using this knowledge and with support from a network of learning communities, they will develop materials and assessments that emphasize active learning and student engagement. Community leaders will receive additional training on grassroots leadership and organizational change in higher education. These leaders will demonstrate the value of active learning techniques, encouraging faculty who are more hesitant to make changes in their courses. Engaging a large number of faculty members, along with administrators who can promote these efforts more widely, will help change teaching norms throughout the university.

The project will investigate how course-based communities of transformation can be used to develop a culture of active and inquiry-based learning in STEM. A significant body of research has shown that active and inquiry-based learning improves student attitudes, retention, and understanding, particularly for underrepresented groups in STEM. Nevertheless, motivating faculty to change their teaching practices remains a challenge. Course-based communities of transformation in the Mathematics, Physics, Biology, and Computer Science Departments will lead instructional changes in specified high-enrollment undergraduate courses. Learning communities that span departments and include key university leadership will support the course-based communities and provide top-down efforts to complement the bottom-up course-focused change. Through analysis of interviews, surveys, course materials, and other key documents, the project will examine how the culture change process unfolds at the faculty, department, and organizational levels. Analysis will also focus on the relationship between department-level change and organizational learning. Combined with a better understanding of organizational change within the university setting, the multi-generational community of transformation model will help other institutions succeed in efforts to change their own campus teaching cultures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO

por.por_cntn:
This project evaluated the Gateway2STEM project at George Mason University (GMU). The GMU team sought to develop a university culture that values and incorporates inquiry-based learning practices in undergraduate gateway courses that provide (or prohibit) entrée  to majors in STEM and STEM-depending fields. They worked through course-based communities of transformation (CCTs) in academic departments to plan and implement approaches to spark course-and department-level change and to foster a local culture that values inquiry-based learning. Three CCTs (in math, physics and CS, rolled out in that order) each focused on infusing active and collaborative learning (ACL) into recitation sections that supplement lecture periods in gateway courses in calculus, introductory physics, and introduction to programming.

To assess the extent to which the intended instructional changes had occurred, we gathered student survey data from gateway courses in math, physics, and CS, in 2021 and 2023. Some were already applying ACL to recitations and some were not. Student views provided an independent perspective on whether active and collaborative (ACL) learning approaches were being used in their recitation sections, and how much this mattered (or not) to their learning environment and their learning..

For analysis, we derived a simple scale (S-ACL) to measure the extent of ACL reported by students as occurring in their recitation, and assessed its validity using the combined data set, over 2000 student responses. We also compared S-ACL means for specific course sections to matched data from instructors and from observations. Finally, we compared S-ACL means for the whole project and for the three departments over time.

We found the S-ACL measure to be informative to measure progress toward the project’s goals of infusing ACL into recitations (Figure 1). In 2021, students in targeted courses experienced more active and collaborative learning than those in courses not affected yet by the project. By 2023, all courses were targeted, and the level of ACL had risen dramatically across the sample. The changes in S-ACL means for departments further illustrate this by showing the progression of ACL implementation in each, starting at different times.

Observation data provided some ground-truthing for the student survey data. Problem-solving activities during group and/or individual work were common in all types of recitations. On the whole, the observed uses of class time do reflect the project’s strategy to devote significant recitation time to student work on inquiry-style tasks in a collaborative, instructor-supported environment.

The S-ACL was used to measure the presence of instruction aimed at active and collaborative learning. It also correlated positively and strongly with two established survey measures that relate to the quality of such teaching, from students’ point of view. The ACL score correlated positively with students’ ratings of the learning environment, and with students’ self-reported learning gains. That is, classes with higher S‑ACL averages-- where students reported that more active and collaborative learning occurred--were also reported to be more engaging, challenging, and interactive, and as generating more learning. We are sharing the survey items and S-ACL scale with other evaluators and researchers through our dissemination activities.

The data in Figure 1 show that the changes are widespread, sustained (in math) and growing (in physics and CS). However, section-by-section variability in teaching is seen in both surveys and observations. This variability means there are still opportunities to strengthen many instructors’ ACL facilitation skills, and to better align assessment practices across sections of a given course. This is important to enhance fairness in student experiences, so that all experience the classroom culture, individual feedback and assessment standards that will support their learning and their attitudes and beliefs about their own capabilities. Observation data in particular offer insight about the strengths of the teaching methods as implemented, and point to areas for further improvement.

The project's communities of practice have been a workable way to engage faculty and GTAs in the joint effort to infuse ACL into recitations, and demonstrate some success of the grassroots leadership model they used. Yet there are limits to what grassroots leadership teams can do to permanently change the operations of gateway courses, which are large, complex, and subject to many forces that act to preserve the status quo. Institutional structures are important, to make new cultural habits the easiest practical path for instructors and thus to protect the newly broadened reforms from backsliding. Supportive structures that could help to institutionalize the teaching reforms made so far would include formalized coordination of large, multi-section courses; mechanisms to establish ACL as a formal departmental commitment in gateway courses; systematic and sustained professional development of GTAs and newly hired instructors; and changes to the reward structure to recognize participation and leadership in a CCT as a mechanism for sustaining the reforms. These are nontrivial changes but important ones to secure the instructional gains made in this project.
